Purpose. Federal regulations should not predetermine economic winners and losers. Yet some regulations operate to exclude new market entrants. Regulations that reduce competition, entrepreneurship, and innova- tion as well as the benefits they create for American consumers should be eliminated. This order commences the process for eliminating anti-com- petitive regulations to revitalize the American economy. Sec. 2. Definitions. (a)  Agency  has the meaning given to it in section 3502 of title 44, United States Code, except that it does not include the Executive Office of the President or any components thereof. (b)  Agency head  means the highest-ranking official of an agency, such as the Secretary, Administrator, Chairman, or Director, unless otherwise specified in this order. Sec. 3. Rescinding Anti-Competitive Regulations. (a) Agency heads shall, in consultation with the Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission (Chair- man) and the Attorney General, complete a review of all regulations subject to their rulemaking authority and identify those that: (i) create, or facilitate the creation of, de facto or de jure monopolies; (ii) create unnecessary barriers to entry for new market participants; (iii) limit competition between competing entities or have the effect of limiting competition between competing entities; (iv) create or facilitate licensure or accreditation requirements that unduly limit competition; (v) unnecessarily burden the agency s procurement processes, thereby lim- iting companies  ability to compete for procurements; or (vi) otherwise impose anti-competitive restraints or distortions on the oper- ation of the free market. (b) Within 70 days of the date of this order, agency heads shall each provide to the Chairman and the Attorney General a list of regulations identified by the categories specified in subsection (a) of this section. Agency heads shall also include a recommendation as to whether each of the listed regulations warrants rescission or modification in light of its anti-competitive effects. For recommended modifications, agency heads shall briefly specify what modification is appropriate. For regulations that are anti-competitive by design, agency heads shall provide a justification for their anti-competitive effects if the agency head is not proposing rescission or modification. (c) In conducting the review required by subsection (a) of this section, agency heads shall prioritize review of those rules that satisfy the definition of  significant regulatory action  in Executive Order 12866 of September 30, 1993 (Regulatory Planning and Review), as amended. (d) Within 10 days of the date of this order, the Chairman shall issue a request for information (RFI) that seeks public input on the identification of regulations that fall within the categories specified in subsection (a) of this section, as well as comments explaining the proposed classifications. The request shall remain open for 40 days. Policy Analysis Summary

1. Policy Text Summary:
The GSA memorandum dated January 13, 2023, provides guidance on the Fiscal Year 2023 Capital Investment Program. Key points include:
- Total Capital Budget of $2,159,893,000
- Increased escalation authority from 10% to 20% for New Construction and Acquisition (BA51) and Major Repairs and Alterations (BA55) projects
- Detailed funding allocations for various construction and renovation projects
- Guidance on project procurement and approval processes

2. Executive Order Summary:
Executive Order 14267 (April 9, 2025) aims to:
- Reduce anti-competitive regulatory barriers
- Require agencies to review and identify regulations that:
  a) Create monopolies
  b) Limit market competition
  c) Create unnecessary entry barriers
  d) Impose anti-competitive restraints
- Mandate a comprehensive review of existing regulations
- Establish a process for potential rescission or modification of anti-competitive regulations

3. Applicability of Executive Order:
The executive order DOES apply to this GSA policy for the following reasons:
- The policy involves procurement and investment processes
- The escalation authority and project approval mechanisms could potentially be viewed as creating regulatory barriers
- The order specifically targets regulations that might limit competition in government processes

4. Recommended Next Steps for Compliance:
a) Conduct a thorough review of the Capital Investment Program guidelines
b) Assess how current escalation authorities and project approval processes might create market entry barriers
c) Prepare documentation justifying the current regulatory approach
d) Be prepared to provide detailed explanations of how current processes:
   - Do not unduly limit market competition
   - Ensure fair and open procurement
   - Provide equal opportunities for different market participants
e) Collaborate with the Federal Trade Commission and Attorney General's office to validate the current regulatory approach
f) Be ready to modify guidelines if anti-competitive elements are identified

Recommendation: While the current policy appears to provide flexibility (20% escalation authority), a proactive review should be conducted to ensure full compliance with the executive order's intent of promoting market competition.

## Policy Analysis Summary

### 1. Brief Summary of Policy Document
The GSA memorandum from January 13, 2023, provides guidance on the FY 2023 Capital Investment Program execution following Congressional appropriations. The document outlines that GSA requested $2.16 billion but received only $1.47 billion in appropriations. It provides operational guidance for regional directors on budget execution, project approvals, and fund allocation processes. The memo specifically addresses construction and acquisition programs, prospectus project approvals, and procedural requirements for project implementation.

### 2. Brief Summary of Executive Order
Executive Order 14267, dated April 9, 2025, titled "Reducing Anti-Competitive Regulatory Barriers," directs federal agencies to identify and eliminate regulations that reduce competition, create barriers to market entry, or facilitate monopolistic practices. The order requires agency heads to review all regulations under their authority and identify those that: create monopolies, impose unnecessary barriers to entry, limit competition, create burdensome licensing requirements, unnecessarily burden procurement processes, or impose anti-competitive restraints on free market operations.

### 3. Detailed Explanation of Executive Order Applicability
This executive order **does apply** to the GSA policy document, but with important distinctions:

**Areas of Potential Impact:**
- **Procurement Processes**: The executive order specifically targets regulations that "unnecessarily burden the agency's procurement processes, thereby limiting companies' ability to compete for procurements" (Section 3(a)(v)). The GSA memorandum establishes procedural requirements for project approvals, fund allocation, and bid processes that could potentially limit competition.
- **Regulatory Authority**: As a federal agency, GSA falls under the executive order's scope and must review its regulations and procedures.

**Limited Direct Impact:**
- The memorandum is primarily an **internal operational guidance document** rather than a public-facing regulation that directly affects market competition.
- The funding limitations and approval processes described are largely driven by Congressional appropriations and statutory requirements rather than discretionary GSA regulations.
- The procedural requirements (such as House and Senate approvals for prospectus projects) are mandated by law rather than agency choice.

**Key Consideration:**
While this specific memorandum may not directly create anti-competitive barriers, the underlying GSA regulations and procedures that govern capital investment programs, procurement processes, and contractor selection criteria would need review under this executive order.

### 4. Next Steps to Achieve Compliance

1. **Comprehensive Regulatory Review**: GSA should conduct a thorough review of all regulations governing capital investment programs, construction procurement, and contractor selection processes to identify potential anti-competitive elements.

2. **Stakeholder Consultation**: Engage with the Federal Trade Commission Chairman and Attorney General as required by the executive order to assess current procurement and project approval processes.

3. **Process Streamlining**: Evaluate whether current procedural requirements for project approvals, bid submissions, and contractor qualifications create unnecessary barriers to market entry.

4. **Documentation Review**: Examine whether requirements for prospectus project approvals, funding allocations, and regional coordination create competitive disadvantages for certain market participants.

5. **Timeline Compliance**: Establish a timeline for completing the regulatory review and implementing any necessary changes to ensure compliance with the executive order's mandates.

6. **Monitoring Implementation**: Develop mechanisms to ensure future policy documents and operational guidance align with anti-competitive regulatory reduction goals.

**Final Determination: [Affected]**

Executive Order 14267 focuses on "Reducing Anti-Competitive Regulatory Barriers" and aims to eliminate regulations that exclude market entrants, reduce competition, entrepreneurship, and innovation. The domain is **regulatory reform to promote market competition**.

1. **Policy Domain**: Federal budget execution and internal GSA financial management procedures for capital investment programs.

2. **Executive Order Domain**: Elimination of anti-competitive regulatory barriers that prevent market entry and reduce competition.

Approach To Low Embodied Carbon Material Internal GSA Use Only - Page 4 As indicated above, IRA Section 60503 provides GSA with $2.15 billion for acquisition and installation of construction materials and products with substantially lower levels of embodied greenhouse gas emissions as compared to estimated industry averages, as determined by the Administrator of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). In December 2022, EPA issued an Interim Determination which provided GSA with guidance on how to identify clean building materials. Consistent with standard GSA practice and the Federal Acquisition Regulation, and taking extensive industry feedback into consideration, GSA issued IRA Low Embodied Carbon (LEC) asphalt, concrete (and cement), glass and steel materials requirements for use in acquiring compliant materials. In addition to these materials, the requirements apply to certain product assemblies if at least 80% of the assembly s total cost or total weight comprises materials that meet the LEC Requirements. In addition to acquiring and installing LEC materials, GSA needs to acquire and install high- performance green building measures and emerging and sustainable technologies. To accomplish this end, GSA needs to generate implementing solicitations and contract documents. This Desk Guide provides guidance instructing Contracting Officers and PBS Project Teams (i.e., Project Executives, Project Managers, Architect/Engineers, and Construction Managers) on incorporating IRA-funded work into required solicitations and agreements.1 This guidance supplements, and does not eliminate, other generally applicable procurement requirements (e.g., competition requirements and the Buy American and Trade Agreement Acts). The ARB should occur prior to the preparation of the document that will need the SPE s signature. 8.A.2 Preparing for the ARB The ARBs should focus on high-level considerations, covering the topics identified at GSAM 504.7102(d). The contracting activity shall prepare slides in advance in Google slides using this ARB Template . Do not edit the template. Instead, make a copy of the template. EO_Text: Federal Register Vol. 90, No. 17 Tuesday, January 28, 2025 Title 3  The President Presidential Documents 8233 Proclamation 10885 of January 20, 2025 Flying the Flag of the United States at Full-Staff on Inau- guration Day By the President of the United States of America A Proclamation By the authority vested in me by the Constitution and the laws of the United States of America, and in honor of Inauguration Day and everything good and noble that it represents about our Nation, our people, and our form of Government, I hereby order that, on this and all future Inauguration Days, the flag of the United States shall be flown at full-staff. Accordingly, I hereby order that the flag of the United States shall be flown at full-staff at the White House and upon all public buildings and grounds, at all military posts and naval stations, and on all naval vessels of the Federal Government, in the District of Columbia and throughout the United States and its Territories and possessions, for the remainder of this day beginning immediately. I also direct that, for the same period of time, the flag shall be flown at full-staff at all United States embassies, legations, consular offices, and other facilities abroad, including all military facilities and naval vessels and stations. ## Policy Analysis Summary

### 1. Brief Summary of the Policy Text
GSA Public Buildings Service Procurement Instructional Bulletin 23-01 establishes mandatory use of the Professional Acquisition Training Highway (PATH) tool for the acquisition workforce. The policy requires all PBS 1102 contract specialists at GS-09 level and below hired after the effective date to complete scenario-based training exercises covering Pre-Award, Award, Post-Award, and Other acquisition modules. The training is part of the SEED program designed to enhance acquisition skills and minimize knowledge gaps in the contracting community.

### 2. Brief Summary of the Executive Order Text
Presidential Proclamation 10885 of January 20, 2025, orders that the U.S. flag be flown at full-staff on Inauguration Day (and all future Inauguration Days) at all federal facilities including the White House, public buildings and grounds, military installations, naval stations, vessels, embassies, and consular offices. After Inauguration Day ends, the flag returns to half-staff per previous Proclamation 10876 honoring former President Carter until the 30-day mourning period concludes.

### 3. Detailed Explanation of Executive Order Applicability
This executive order does **not apply** to the PBS acquisition training policy. The executive order addresses flag display protocols on federal properties and has no intersection with personnel training requirements, acquisition procedures, or workforce development policies. The executive order is a ceremonial directive concerning flag etiquette, while the PBS policy governs internal training mandates for acquisition personnel. These are entirely separate regulatory domains with no overlapping provisions or requirements.

### 4. Next Steps for Compliance
No compliance actions are required as the executive order does not affect this policy. GSA PBS should continue implementing the PATH training requirements as outlined in PIB 23-01 without modification.

**Final Determination: [Not Affected]**

Policy Text: GENERAL SERVICES ADMINISTRATION Washington, DC 20405 GSA ORDER SUBJECT: Sustainability Performance 1. Purpose. PBS 1098.1 January 11, 2023 This Order directs and reiterates the Public Buildings Service s (PBS) continued commitment to sustainability performance across the owned and leased real property portfolio. The Order s overarching goals are to improve asset performance; reduce energy use, water use, waste generation, and greenhouse gas emissions; increase the number of all-electric buildings, net zero energy, and high performance sustainable Federal buildings; and achieve portfolio-wide net zero operational emissions by 2045. This Order supports proper focus, engagement, collaboration, planning, and accountability across PBS business lines and regions. 2. Background. GSA is a key leader in the Federal Government s real estate management and optimization efforts. PBS is charged with designing, constructing, operating, and maintaining a right-sized and sustainable Federal building portfolio that supports Federal operations now and for future generations. PBS expects to experience long- term increases in energy and water costs, and there are growing concerns about air quality, environmental stewardship, and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. PBS is taking action by deploying policies and programs to control operating costs, reduce environmental impacts, and improve overall building performance. Sustainability performance goals include but are not limited to:   Reduction of Greenhouse Gas Emissions;   Generation and Purchase of Carbon Pollution-Free Electricity;   Reduction of Energy and Water Usage, and Generation of Solid Waste;   Enhanced Indoor Environmental Quality;   Reduction of Operating Costs; 1 DocuSign Envelope ID: EB036CCD-245A-4ADA-A165-0DD7427071E2 PBS 1098.1   Development and Utilization of Specifications for Sustainable Materials and Products;   Locating, Designing, and Reinvesting into Federal Facilities to Promote Sustainable and Equitable Development;   Promoting Environmental Justice in Neighboring Communities;   Designing, Constructing, and Operating Sustainable and Resilient Buildings; and   Incorporating Regenerative Systems. The continued transformation of the PBS portfolio to meet new post-pandemic future of work customer requirements will help advance flexible and innovative solutions to meet the evolving workplace needs of diverse customer agencies. Further transitioning to a high performance sustainable Federal portfolio will help PBS cost-effectively maintain and improve its workplace solutions for the long-term benefit of both tenants and American taxpayers. 3. Scope and Applicability. This Order applies to all PBS business lines, programs, and initiatives that involve acquisition, planning, design, construction, operation, maintenance, lease, renovation, and disposal of Federally-owned facilities. Nothing in this Order changes the applicability and policy of when and how the GSA Facilities Standards for the Public Buildings Service applies to projects. 4. Policy. This Order formalizes core business practices, roles, and guidelines for PBS to achieve its sustainability performance goals. All PBS business lines must ensure appropriate policies, procedures, and measures are in place to provide for the continued use, appropriate care, and enhanced sustainability of Federally-owned buildings and leased space. Each PBS business line and region will update or expand its policies, guidance, and business practices as necessary to implement this Order. This Order supports existing PBS, GSA, and Federal mandates or policies including but not limited to:   PBS Strategic Plan 2022-26;   GSA Facilities Standards for the Public Buildings Service (P100);   GSA Sustainability Plan 2022;   GSA Agency Performance Plan;   GSA Strategic Plan 2022-26;   White House Council on Environmental Quality (CEQ), Guiding Principles for Sustainable Federal Buildings (Guiding Principles);   CEQ, Federal Building Performance Standard; DocuSign Envelope ID: EB036CCD-245A-4ADA-A165-0DD7427071E2 PBS 1098.1   48 C.F.R. Governance and Engagement. PBS business lines and regional leaders shall participate in, engage with, and support PBS sustainability governance bodies. Regional Commissioners (or their proxies) shall chair, re-establish, and support Regional Sustainability Councils (RSCs). New or existing cross functional teams should be established across business lines at the implementation, planning, and/or senior level as needed. Challenges should be raised to regional leadership and shared for visibility with the Regional Sustainability Council, the PBS National Sustainability Council (NSC), and, as appropriate, the PBS Sustainability Governance Board (SGB). b. Strategy. PBS business lines and regions will be held accountable for developing and complying with all current and forthcoming strategies, initiatives, actions, and measures to ensure goals of this Order are met. All business lines and divisions shall utilize sustainability status and building-level performance data for energy, water, waste, and GHG to set goals, milestones, and strategic plans. DocuSign Envelope ID: EB036CCD-245A-4ADA-A165-0DD7427071E2 PBS 1098.1 c. Sustainability Plans. PBS Regional Commissioners must establish a sustainability implementation plan (SIP) for their respective regions within 120 days of the date of this Order and update it annually thereafter. EO_Text: Federal Register / Vol. 90, No. 19 / Thursday, January 30, 2025 / Presidential Documents 8621 Presidential Documents Executive Order 14170 of January 20, 2025 Reforming the Federal Hiring Process and Restoring Merit to Government Service By the authority vested in me as President by the Constitution and the laws of the United States of America, including sections 3301, 3302, and 7511 of title 5, United States Code, it is hereby ordered: Section 1. Policy. American citizens deserve an excellent and efficient Federal workforce that attracts the highest caliber of civil servants committed to achieving the freedom, prosperity, and democratic rule that our Constitution promotes. But current Federal hiring practices are broken, insular, and out- dated. They no longer focus on merit, practical skill, and dedication to our Constitution. Federal hiring should not be based on impermissible factors, such as one s commitment to illegal racial discrimination under the guise of  equity,  or one s commitment to the invented concept of  gender iden- tity  over sex. Inserting such factors into the hiring process subverts the will of the People, puts critical government functions at risk, and risks losing the best-qualified candidates. By making our recruitment and hiring processes more efficient and focused on serving the Nation, we will ensure that the Federal workforce is prepared to help achieve American greatness, and attracts the talent necessary to serve our citizens effectively. By significantly improving hiring principles and practices, Americans will receive the Federal resources and services they deserve from the highest-skilled Federal workforce in the world. Sec. 2. ## Policy Analysis Summary

### 1. Brief Summary of Policy Text
The GSA FAS memorandum from January 9, 2023, establishes procedures for resolving interagency policy differences in acquisition activities. It requires Contracting Officers (COs) to document their decision-making process and consult with the Office of General Counsel and FAS Office of Policy and Compliance when choosing to follow a requesting agency's less restrictive policy over GSA's standard procedures. The policy applies to all FAS activities awarding contracts, Blanket Purchase Agreements, or orders through interagency acquisitions.

### 2. Brief Summary of Executive Order Text
Executive Order 14263, dated April 9, 2025, targets Susman Godfrey LLP specifically, prohibiting federal agencies from providing taxpayer funds, contracts, or access to classified information to this law firm. The order cites concerns about the firm's activities allegedly undermining American interests, including efforts to "weaponize the American legal system," degrade election quality, undermine military effectiveness through political ideology, and engage in what the order characterizes as unlawful racial discrimination through diversity programs.

### 3. Detailed Explanation of Executive Order Applicability
This executive order **directly affects** the GSA policy. Here's why:

- **Scope Intersection**: The GSA policy governs interagency acquisitions, including contracts and agreements, while the executive order prohibits federal contracting with Susman Godfrey LLP.

- **Implementation Mechanism**: When GSA serves as the servicing agency in interagency acquisitions, the consultation and documentation procedures outlined in the policy would need to account for the executive order's prohibitions.

- **Policy Conflict Resolution**: The existing policy's framework for resolving interagency differences must now incorporate the executive order's blanket prohibition, regardless of whether a requesting agency has less restrictive policies regarding Susman Godfrey.

- **Documentation Requirements**: The "Memorandum for Record" requirement would need modification to include verification that proposed contractors are not Susman Godfrey LLP or its affiliates.

**Immediate Actions:**
1. **Update Documentation Templates**: Revise Attachment A (Memorandum for Record template) to include a mandatory section verifying that the proposed contractor is not Susman Godfrey LLP.

2. **Amend Consultation Procedures**: Modify the consultation process with OGC and OPC to include screening for Executive Order 14263 compliance during policy difference resolution.

3. **Training and Communication**: Issue guidance to all FAS COs explaining that Executive Order 14263 supersedes any requesting agency's less restrictive policies regarding Susman Godfrey LLP.

1. Add a new subsection addressing executive order compliance in interagency acquisitions

1. Establish monitoring procedures to ensure continued compliance
2. Regular updates to prohibited entity lists as new executive orders or regulations emerge
3. Coordination with GSA's suspension and debarment officials

Policy. American citizens deserve an excellent and efficient Federal workforce that attracts the highest caliber of civil servants committed to achieving the freedom, prosperity, and democratic rule that our Constitution promotes. But current Federal hiring practices are broken, insular, and out- dated. They no longer focus on merit, practical skill, and dedication to our Constitution. Federal hiring should not be based on impermissible factors, such as one s commitment to illegal racial discrimination under the guise of  equity,  or one s commitment to the invented concept of  gender iden- tity  over sex. Inserting such factors into the hiring process subverts the will of the People, puts critical government functions at risk, and risks losing the best-qualified candidates. By making our recruitment and hiring processes more efficient and focused on serving the Nation, we will ensure that the Federal workforce is prepared to help achieve American greatness, and attracts the talent necessary to serve our citizens effectively. By significantly improving hiring principles and practices, Americans will receive the Federal resources and services they deserve from the highest-skilled Federal workforce in the world. Sec. 2. Federal Hiring Plan. (a) Within 120 days of the date of this order, the Assistant to the President for Domestic Policy, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, the Director of the Office of Personnel Management, and the Administrator of the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), shall develop and send to agency heads a Federal Hiring Plan that brings to the Federal workforce only highly skilled Americans dedicated to the furtherance of American ideals, values, and interests. (b) This Federal Hiring Plan shall: (i) prioritize recruitment of individuals committed to improving the effi- ciency of the Federal government, passionate about the ideals of our American republic, and committed to upholding the rule of law and the United States Constitution; (ii) prevent the hiring of individuals based on their race, sex, or religion, and prevent the hiring of individuals who are unwilling to defend the Constitution or to faithfully serve the Executive Branch; (iii) implement, to the greatest extent possible, technical and alternative assessments as required by the Chance to Compete Act of 2024; (iv) decrease government-wide time-to-hire to under 80 days; (v) improve communication with candidates to provide greater clarity regarding application status, timelines, and feedback, including regular updates on the progress of applications and explanations of hiring decisions where appropriate; (vi) integrate modern technology to support the recruitment and selection process, including the use of data analytics to identify trends, gaps, and VerDate Sep<11>2014 18:45 Jan 29, 2025 Jkt 265001 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 4790 Sfmt 4790 E:\FR\FM\30JAE9.SGM 30JAE9 5 1 C O D Z E R P _ R F h t i w D O R P 3 2 N Q X 1 1 K S D n o r e t t o l 8622 Federal Register / Vol. 90, No. 19 / Thursday, January 30, 2025 / Presidential Documents opportunities in hiring, as well as leveraging digital platforms to improve candidate engagement; and (vii) ensure Department and Agency leadership, or their designees, are active participants in implementing the new processes and throughout the full hiring process. (c) This Federal Hiring Plan shall include specific agency plans to improve the allocation of Senior Executive Service positions in the Cabinet agencies, the Environmental Protection Agency, the Office of Management and Budget, the Small Business Administration, the Social Security Administration, the National Science Foundation, the Office of Personnel Management, and the General Services Administration, to best facilitate democratic leadership, as required by law, within each agency. (d) The Federal Hiring Plan shall provide specific best practices for the human resources function in each agency, which each agency head shall implement, with advice and recommendations as appropriate from DOGE. Sec. 3. Accountability and Reporting. (a) The Director of the Office of Per- sonnel Management shall establish clear performance metrics to evaluate the success of these reforms, and request agency analysis on a regular basis. (b) The Office of Personnel Management shall consult with Federal agen- cies, labor organizations, and other stakeholders to monitor progress and ensure that the reforms are meeting the needs of both candidates and agencies.
